mainEntity.name: What is the best free LLM monitoring tool in 2025?

acceptedAnswer.text: Phoenix by Arize is the best free LLM monitoring tool in 2025. It's completely open source with no restrictions, offering tracing, evaluations, prompt management, and hallucination detection. You can self-host it anywhere (Docker, Kubernetes, cloud) and it's built on OpenTelemetry to avoid vendor lock-in.

mainEntity.name: How does Langfuse compare to LangSmith?

acceptedAnswer.text: Langfuse vs LangSmith comparison: Langfuse is open-source (MIT license) and framework-agnostic, while LangSmith is proprietary and optimized for LangChain. Langfuse offers self-hosting without restrictions and costs less at scale. LangSmith has better debugging for LangChain users and tighter integration. Choose Langfuse if you want data ownership and flexibility, LangSmith if you're deep in the LangChain ecosystem.

mainEntity.name: Which LLM monitoring tool has the fastest setup?

acceptedAnswer.text: Helicone has the fastest setup among LLM monitoring tools - typically under 2 minutes. You simply change your API base URL and you're done. No SDK installation, no code changes required. The proxy architecture adds only 50-80ms latency while providing caching, rate limiting, and threat detection out of the box.

mainEntity.name: What LLM monitoring tools support EU AI Act compliance?

acceptedAnswer.text: For EU AI Act compliance, Fiddler AI, Arize AI, and Langtrace offer explicit support. They provide immutable audit trails, transparency logging (Articles 50-56), bias detection, hallucination tracking, and human-in-the-loop tracking. The EU AI Act penalties are up to €35 million or 7% of global annual turnover, making compliant monitoring critical for regulated industries.

mainEntity.name: How can I reduce LLM costs with observability tools?

acceptedAnswer.text: LLM observability tools reduce costs through: 1) Response caching (15-30% reduction with Helicone or Langfuse), 2) Smart routing to cheaper models for simple queries, 3) Prompt optimization (30-50% reduction via better engineering), and 4) Output token monitoring since output tokens cost 3-5x more than input tokens. Most teams discover cost issues after receiving unexpected $3,600+ invoices.

mainEntity.name: Which LLM monitoring tool is best for enterprises?

acceptedAnswer.text: For enterprises, Arize AI offers the most comprehensive platform ($50k+/year) with agent-level tracing, SOC 2/HIPAA/GDPR compliance, and enterprise deployment options. Datadog LLM Observability is best if you're already using Datadog for infrastructure. Fiddler AI is optimal if compliance and guardrails are your top priority with sub-100ms response times.

about.name: EU AI Act
about.description: European Union regulation on artificial intelligence

about.name: Article 12
about.description: Record-keeping requirements for high-risk AI systems

about.name: Compliance Logging
about.description: Automatic event recording for regulatory compliance

@graph.name: How to Implement EU AI Act Article 12 Compliance Logging
@graph.description: Step-by-step implementation guide for EU AI Act Article 12 compliant logging with code examples for Python and TypeScript applications.

supply.name: Log storage backend (PostgreSQL, MongoDB, or S3)

step.name: Design Your Log Schema
step.text: Create a JSON schema that captures all Article 12 required fields including event_id, timestamp, event_type, system_id, session data, input/output hashes, model information, human oversight records, and risk indicators.

itemListElement.text: Define required fields: event_id (UUID), timestamp (ISO 8601), event_type (enum), system_id
Add session tracking: session_id, start_time, end_time
Include input/output data: hashes instead of raw content for privacy, token counts, content types
Record model information: name, version, provider
Track human oversight: verifier_id, action, timestamp
Add risk indicators: confidence thresholds, anomaly detection, review flags

step.name: Implement Compliance Logger (Python)
step.text: Build a Python compliance logger class that automatically records all AI operations with proper traceability, including inference events, human overrides, errors, and system changes.

itemListElement.text: Create ComplianceLogEntry dataclass with all required fields
Implement ComplianceLogger class with automatic event recording
Add methods for log_inference, log_human_override, log_error, log_system_change
Use SHA-256 hashing for input/output content to avoid storing PII
Implement confidence threshold checking with automatic review flags

step.name: Implement Compliance Logger (TypeScript)
step.text: Create TypeScript/Node.js version of the compliance logger with type-safe interfaces and async storage operations for enterprise applications.

itemListElement.text: Define TypeScript interfaces for ComplianceLogEntry and LogStorageBackend
Create ComplianceLogger class with async methods
Implement logInference, logHumanOverride, logError with Promise returns
Use crypto module for SHA-256 hashing and UUID generation

step.name: Configure Storage and Retention
step.text: Set up tiered storage architecture with hot, warm, cold, and archive tiers to manage compliance logs over system lifetime with appropriate retention policies.

itemListElement.text: Configure hot storage (0-30 days) using PostgreSQL or MongoDB for fast queries
Set up warm storage (30-365 days) with S3 or Azure Blob for compressed JSON
Implement cold storage (1-7+ years) using Glacier or archive tier
Configure regulatory hold with WORM storage for legal requirements
Set retention policies: minimum system lifetime, recommended 7-10 years

step.name: Build Audit Trails with Hash Chains
step.text: Implement hash-chained logging to create tamper-evident audit trails without blockchain complexity, ensuring log integrity for regulatory inspection.

itemListElement.text: Create HashChainedLogger class wrapping ComplianceLogger
Add chain metadata to each log entry: previous_hash, sequence, entry_hash
Compute deterministic SHA-256 hash of each entry
Link entries by including previous entry hash
Implement verify_chain method for integrity validation

step.name: Test and Validate Compliance
step.text: Write comprehensive test suite to verify Article 12 compliance including required fields, timestamp formats, risk detection, human oversight tracking, and hash integrity.

itemListElement.text: Test all required fields are present in logged events
Verify timestamps are ISO 8601 with timezone
Validate low confidence triggers review flags
Test human override links to original events
Verify input hashing provides deterministic traceability
Run compliance checklist before production deployment

itemListElement.name: EU AI Act Compliance Logging Setup

mainEntity.name: How much does GPT-4 cost per token?

acceptedAnswer.text: GPT-4o costs $2.50 per million input tokens and $10.00 per million output tokens. GPT-4o mini is significantly cheaper at $0.15 per million input tokens and $0.60 per million output tokens.

mainEntity.name: What is the cheapest LLM API in 2025?

acceptedAnswer.text: DeepSeek V3 is currently the cheapest major LLM API at $0.27 per million input tokens and $1.10 per million output tokens, making it roughly 10x cheaper than GPT-4o for input-heavy workloads.

mainEntity.name: How can I reduce my OpenAI API costs?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most effective ways to reduce OpenAI costs are: 1) Use GPT-4o mini instead of GPT-4o for simpler tasks (94% cheaper), 2) Enable prompt caching for repeated context (90% savings on cache hits), 3) Use the Batch API for non-urgent requests (50% discount), and 4) Optimize prompts to reduce token usage.

Claude Sonnet 4.5 costs $3.00/$15.00 per million tokens (input/output) compared to GPT-4o at $2.50/$10.00. GPT-4o is slightly cheaper for most workloads, but Claude Haiku at $1.00/$5.00 is competitive with GPT-4o mini for lightweight tasks.

mainEntity.name: What is prompt caching and how much does it save?

acceptedAnswer.text: Prompt caching stores frequently-used prompt prefixes so you don't pay full price for repeated context. Anthropic's prompt caching charges 90% less for cached tokens. For applications with system prompts or repeated context, this can reduce input costs by 50-90%.

@graph.name: How to Migrate from WhyLabs to Integrity Studio
@graph.description: Step-by-step guide to migrate your AI observability from WhyLabs to Integrity Studio before the March 9, 2025 shutdown deadline.

step.name: Export Your WhyLabs Data
step.text: Download data profiles, export alert configurations, save custom metric definitions, and document monitoring thresholds.

step.name: Create Integrity Studio Account
step.text: Sign up at integritystudio.ai, configure organization and team members, set up SSO if needed, and generate API keys.

step.name: Install SDK and Update Integration Code
step.text: Install Integrity Studio SDK, update import statements, migrate logging calls, and configure environment variables.

step.name: Recreate Monitors and Alerts
step.text: Configure drift monitors, set up data quality checks, create alert rules and notification channels.

step.name: Run Parallel Monitoring
step.text: Send data to both platforms, compare drift detection results, verify alert thresholds, train team on new dashboard.

step.name: Complete Migration
step.text: Remove WhyLabs SDK, update documentation, verify all monitors are active, archive exported data.

mainEntity.name: Can I keep using whylogs with Integrity Studio?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes! whylogs remains open source and actively maintained. Integrity Studio can ingest whylogs profiles directly, so you can keep your existing data logging code and only change where profiles are sent.

LangKit also remains open source. However, Integrity Studio includes equivalent (and enhanced) LLM metrics built-in, so you may not need LangKit at all. If you prefer LangKit's specific metrics, you can use both together.

mainEntity.name: Is there a free tier for WhyLabs refugees?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes. We're offering an extended free trial (60 days vs standard 14 days) for teams migrating from WhyLabs. Contact us with your WhyLabs organization ID for verification.

mainEntity.name: How long does migration typically take?

acceptedAnswer.text: For most teams, the full migration takes 1-2 weeks. Day 1 for data export and account setup, Days 2-3 for code updates, Days 4-5 for monitors and alerts, and Days 6-14 for parallel monitoring and validation.

mainEntity.name: What if I need features WhyLabs had that you don't?

acceptedAnswer.text: Let us know! Our roadmap is responsive to customer needs. If there's a WhyLabs feature critical to your workflow that we don't currently offer, email product@integritystudio.ai.
